subject: Art
title: Light & Shadow
description: How light reveals form through a predictable pattern of values.

hook.text: Put a ball under a lamp. You'll see a highlight, a light side, a shadow side, a core shadow, reflected light, and a cast shadow. This pattern applies to EVERY lit object.

buildup.text: The light pattern on a sphere: (1) Highlight â€” brightest spot where light hits directly. (2) Halftone â€” gradually darkening. (3) Core shadow â€” darkest band where the form turns away from light. (4) Reflected light â€” subtle bounce from the surface below. (5) Cast shadow â€” the shadow on the ground.

discovery.text: The core shadow is always the darkest dark on the object itself. The cast shadow is darkest closest to the object and softens as it extends away. This pattern is universal and predictable.

twist.text: Reflected light is the most common trap. Beginners make it too bright, which flattens the form. Reflected light is always darker than the lightest halftone. Keep it subtle.

climax.text: Set up a white ball and a single lamp. Squint and identify all five zones. Draw what you see. Once you see this pattern, you'll see it on every object around you.

punchline.text: Learn the light pattern on a sphere and you can shade anything in existence.

quiz.question: Where is the core shadow on a lit object?
options: The darkest band where the form turns away from light
